explanation:
For a sound unreachable-code (MISRA) analysis we must know the exact semantics, bit-layouts, and limits used by lfs_dir_traverse. Each listed symbol is required as follows:

- LFS_DIR_TRAVERSE_DEPTH: stack array size and the LFS_ASSERT(sp < ...) check determine whether the recursion-to-stack-code path can be saturated or is statically bounded.
- struct lfs_dir_traverse: layout and field types show what state is pushed/popped; needed to verify the correctness of the pop/goto and whether any stored fields could make code unreachable.
- LFS_ASSERT: its expansion/behavior (no-op vs abort) affects whether the sp check can render later code unreachable in compiled builds.
- LFS_MKTAG: macro that composes tag values and masks; used to build masks/ttag/offsets so its bit layout is needed to reason which branches (mask tests, tag arithmetic) can be true.
- lfs_tag_dsize: used in the critical conditional (off + dsize(ptag) < dir->off); its definition (and reliance on tag size/isdelete) decides whether the first branch is ever taken.
- lfs_tag_size: used by lfs_tag_dsize and elsewhere (e.g., iterating user attrs); its semantics determines loop counts and reachability of blocks handling USERATTRS.
- lfs_tag_isdelete: influences lfs_tag_dsize result for delete tags; required to reason about possible sizes and branch outcomes.
- lfs_bd_read: its return/error behavior and side-effects determine reachability of the error-return path and whether the read path is feasible.
- lfs_frombe32: endianness/xor semantics applied to tag read from disk; affects computed tag values used in downstream mask/type checks.
- lfs_tag_id: extracts id bits from tags; used in multiple filters (mask compare and begin/end range) — must know its extraction to decide if those filters can ever pass/fail.
- lfs_tag_type3: extracts the 3-bit (or relevant) type field used to dispatch NOOP/MOVE/USERATTRS/normal — needed to determine which type-specific branches are reachable.
- LFS_FROM_NOOP, LFS_FROM_MOVE, LFS_FROM_USERATTRS: numeric constants identifying tag types; required to evaluate tag-type comparisons and thus reachability of their case blocks.
- LFS_TYPE_USERATTR, LFS_TYPE_STRUCT: used to construct tags for callback invocations and filter ttag/tmask setup; needed to reason whether constructed tag values can match filters and enable recursion.
- struct lfs_attr: layout (fields type, size, buffer) used when iterating USERATTRS — needed to know loop body and whether the cb call path is reachable.
- lfs_dir_traverse_filter: the callback substituted during recursion; the function identity influences the early-continue check (cb == lfs_dir_traverse_filter) that purposely skips MOVE recursion; needed to know whether that skip can occur.
- lfs_t: the filesystem context type (used by lfs_bd_read and other ops) — needed insofar as its fields (e.g. rcache) influence lfs_bd_read outcomes if that affects reachability.
- lfs_mdir_t: directory-in-memory type; specifically the .off and .pair[0] fields are read in condition and used for disk addressing — necessary to determine feasibility of the disk-read branch.
- lfs_mattr: type for attrs[] entries (tag, buffer) used as the alternative source of tags — required to know when the attrs branch is available and how many iterations occur.
- struct lfs_diskoff: type assigned to 'disk' and passed as buffer for disk-backed tags; needed to reason about what buffer values mean to callbacks and whether associated branches run.

Collectively these definitions (macros, tag field extractors, constants, and struct layouts/semantics) are necessary to determine whether conditionals (off+dsize < dir->off; mask tests; tag-type switches; begin/end range checks; cb equality) can ever evaluate to true or false and therefore whether any sub-blocks are statically unreachable.
